related-article.article-title: Preventing harms from first prescriptions of opioids
Preventing harms from first prescriptions of opioids
Prévention des méfaits dès la première prescription d’opioïdes

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The relation between emergency department opioid prescribing and subsequent harm is complex and poorly studied. We sought to quantify adverse outcomes, incremental risk, and rates of prolonged opioid use among emergency department patients receiving an opioid prescription and propensity-matched controls.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We used administrative data to sample all Alberta emergency department visits over 10 years, excluding patients with cancer, palliative care, or concurrent opioid use. Treated patients filled an opioid prescription within 72 hours after their index visit; untreated patients did not. We generated propensity scores to identify matched controls among untreated patients. The 1-year primary composite outcome included opioid-related emergency visits (e.g., overdoses), new opioid agonist therapy, all-cause hospital admission, or death. The secondary outcome was prolonged opioid use.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: After 13 028 575 eligible visits, 689 074 patients (5.3%) filled an opioid prescription. The mean age was 43.9 years, and 49.8% of patients were female. Most were high-acuity patients with traumatic, gastrointestinal–genitourinary, or musculoskeletal complaints. Patients who received opioids experienced 1.4% more primary outcome events (17.1% v. 15.7%), driven by all-cause hospital admissions (16.4% v. 15.1%; number needed to harm [NNH] = 53) and prolonged opioid use (4.5% v. 3.3%; NNH = 59). Opioid-related visits, new opioid agonist treatment, and mortality were unaffected. Incremental risk was low for patients with documented mental health conditions or substance use, and was highest for opioid-naive patients, older patients, and males.

sec.title: Interpretation:
sec.p: Emergency department opioid prescriptions were associated with small increases in subsequent opioid prescription use and hospital admission, particularly in older and opioid-naive patients, and males; they were not associated with overdoses, new opioid agonist therapy, or mortality. Physicians should understand patient-specific incremental risks when prescribing opioids for acute pain.

award-group.funding-source: The Canadian Institutes of Health Research

body.p: Opioid prescriptions are a factor in some overdose-related deaths,1–4 and this awareness has driven substantial reductions in prescribing.5–7 Despite these reductions, mortality has increased, with more than 500 000 opioid-related deaths in North America since 2016.8–10 In Alberta, Canada, the proportion of people who filled an opioid prescription dropped 35% between 2016 and 2021, but opioid-related deaths tripled, from 554 to 1510 per year, largely because of potent opioids in the illegal market.7

The relation between emergency department opioid prescribing and harm is complex.11 Emergency physicians face growing pressure to curtail opioid prescribing12 but must manage severe pain and treat opioid-tolerant patients who can no longer access opioids from their physicians.13 There is little research to guide them.14 The few guidelines that address opioids for acute pain provide generic advice to avoid replacement opioids, potent or sustained-release opioids, high daily doses, and prolonged prescription durations.15–18 None discuss risk stratification or modified approaches for different patients.

Previous studies of opioid prescribing in the emergency department involved mostly older opioid-naive American Medicare populations and assessed a primary outcome of prolonged prescription opioid use, with estimates of number needed to harm (NNH) from 7 to 300 prescriptions to cause an episode of prolonged use.1,2,19,20 Prolonged use is important but not synonymous with adverse health consequences. Therefore, we chose to study additional outcomes.

We sought to quantify, for emergency department patients filling an opioid prescription, the likelihood of adverse outcomes, the incremental risk to opioid-treated patients compared with propensity-matched controls, and rates of prolonged opioid use for these groups.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: We performed a population-based observational cohort study using linked administrative data to sample all patients discharged from an emergency department in the province of Alberta, Canada, over a 10-year period. We adhered to the Reporting of Studies Conducted Using Observational Routinely-Collected Health Data statement.21

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: Patients older than 12 years who were discharged from an Alberta emergency department between January 2010 and June 2020 were eligible. We excluded patients with opioid use disorder or prolonged opioid use (defined below) during the year preceding their index visit. We excluded patients with a cancer diagnosis or who received palliative care in the 6 months before or after their index visit. A patient was deemed to have cancer if data recorded them as having a cancer-related visit, taking chemotherapy, or having active cancer other than nonmelanoma skin cancer in the provincial cancer registry. Patients were deemed as palliative if data recorded an International Classification of Diseases, 10th Revision (ICD-10) code Z51.5. We excluded patients who left against medical advice or were admitted to hospital during their index visit, because they did not have the opportunity to receive prescriptions from the emergency department when they left. Our unit of analysis was the emergency department visit. Patients who had no outcome event during a 1-year washout period were eligible for re-enrolment.

sec.title: Comparator groups
sec.p: Treated patients filled an opioid prescription (codeine, morphine, hydrocodone, hydromorphone, tramadol, meperidine, fentanyl, or oxycodone) within 72 hours after their index visit. Untreated patients did not. We generated propensity scores to identify matched controls among untreated patients.

sec.title: Outcomes
sec.p: The 1-year primary composite outcome included opioid-specific events (opioid-related emergency department visits [ICD-10: F11, T40.0–T40.4 or T40.6], or new opioid agonist therapy), all-cause hospital admission, or death. Opioid-related emergency department visits and new opioid agonist treatment are proxies for progression to opioid use disorder. All-cause hospital admissions reflect major health events, and mortality is the measure most relevant to the opioid epidemic. We included all-cause outcomes because opioids generate diverse harms through gastrointestinal dysfunction, immune suppression, injury, mental illness, and other mechanisms that may not be identified as specific to opioids.22 If no indication was present in the health record that an encounter was related to opioids, we considered it an all-cause event. Secondary outcomes included prolonged opioid use (> 120 days of prescribed opioids), the measure preferred by previous researchers, and cumulative morphine milligram equivalents (MMEs) dispensed 30–365 days after the emergency department visit.19,23 We excluded dispensations between 0 and 30 days to avoid correlation with the index prescription.19

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: Alberta Health Services (AHS) operates all hospitals and compiles health information for all Alberta residents. The AHS Pharmaceutical Information Network records agent, dose, and amount dispensed for all prescriptions. The AHS data warehouse collates patient demographic characteristics and health information, including ICD-10 diagnoses, Canadian Institute for Health Information health conditions, and health profile groups. Health conditions are based on ICD diagnostic codes from the Discharge Abstract Database, the National Ambulatory Care Reporting System, Continuing Care Reporting System, and patient-level billing data. Patients may have several health conditions, so their health status is categorized by mapping these to 239 health profile groups, each based on the most complex conditions. Alberta Health Services analysts linked these data sources and prepared study databases.

sec.title: Covariates
sec.p: We categorized patients by opioid status in the preceding year. Patients with opioid use disorder had an opioid-related ICD-10 code (F11 [mental and behavioural disorders due to opioids], T40.0–T40.4, T40.6 [opioid poisoning]);24,25 a positive opioid toxicology screen; or opioid agonist therapy with methadone, Kadian, or buprenorphine. Patients with prior opioid exposure had 1 or more opioid prescriptions but no opioid use disorder criteria. Opioid-naive patients had no opioid prescriptions and no opioid use disorder criteria. We documented visit time, arrival mode, and acuity, based on the 5-level Canadian Triage and Acuity Score. We captured ICD-10 discharge diagnoses to categorize complaint type, documented length of stay as a visit complexity marker, and recorded the number of emergency department visits in the prior year to determine utilization patterns. We measured demographic characteristics, including age, sex, and socioeconomic status based on Pampalon deprivation quintiles.26 The Pampalon deprivation index is a proxy for socioeconomic status in administrative databases, representing inequality in material resources and social supports. We identified comorbid conditions, including mental health and substance use disorders, at the time of the index visit using health profile groupings. We used Pharmaceutical Information Network data to identify active medications at the time of the emergency department visit, opioid prescriptions at discharge, opioid prescriptions, and cumulative MMEs dispensed after discharge.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: We prepared descriptive summaries of patient characteristics. We developed logistic regression models to generate propensity scores representing the conditional probability of opioid treatment for each eligible visit, using the following covariates: age, sex, complaint type, visit year, visit time (day, evening, night), arrival mode (ambulance v. ambulatory), triage acuity, number of prior emergency department visits, deprivation category, number of documented health conditions, mental health or substance use disorders, psychotropic or analgesic prescriptions within a year, prior opioid exposure status, and index visit length of stay. We used standardized mean differences to assess covariate balance, with discrepancies greater than 0.10 suggesting imbalance.27 Because of the large data set, we randomly partitioned the data into 10 subsets. We used the MatchIt package in R to perform 1-to-1 nearest neighbour matching without replacement within each subset, then combined subset results.28,29 Propensity models were assessed by comparing residual covariate balance, standardized mean differences, and propensity score distributions.30–32

After comparing treated and control groups, we performed a second-level regression using the above variables to adjust for residual covariate imbalance, then estimated the causal effect of an opioid prescription for defined outcomes.33,34 For our primary outcome we calculated adjusted odds ratios (ORs) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs) and determined NNH using adjusted ORs rather than crude risk differences.35,36 Because data on cumulative MME were skewed, we performed a natural log transformation before regression analysis so that the coefficient for treatment would represent a multiplicative effect.

We evaluated subgroups defined by age, sex, previous opioid status, mental health diagnosis, and substance use disorder. We repeated analyses within each subgroup, then used multivariable logistic regression to identify factors associated with adverse outcomes in patients receiving opioids. As with earlier analyses, subgroup evaluations compared treated patients with matched controls.

sec.title: Ethics approval
sec.p: The University of Calgary Research Ethics Board approved this study.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: During the 10-year study, 18 133 370 visits to the emergency department occurred (Figure 1), including 13 028 575 eligible visits. Of these, 689 074 patients (5.3%) filled an opioid prescription. Opioid-treated patients were more likely than untreated patients to have previous opioid prescriptions, high triage acuity, and trauma or musculoskeletal pain. They were less likely to have mental health diagnoses or multiple prior visits. After propensity matching, opioid-treated patients were similar to controls on all measured parameters. The mean age was 43.9 years, and 49.8% of patients were female (Table 1). Most had high triage acuity with traumatic, gastrointestinal–genitourinary, or musculoskeletal complaints. A total of 15.6% had 3 or more emergency visits the previous year, and 4.8% and 3.8%, respectively, had documented mental health or non-opioid substance use disorders.

sec.p: Opioid-treated patients had worse outcomes than controls (Table 2), with a 1.4% increase of absolute risk in the primary composite outcome (17.1% v. 15.7%). After adjustment for residual covariate imbalance, the adjusted OR was 1.15 (95% CI 1.14–1.16), and the number of opioid prescriptions needed to cause 1 primary outcome (NNH) was 52. Composite outcome differences were driven by all-cause hospital admission (16.4% v. 15.1%; adjusted OR 1.15, 95% CI 1.14–1.16; NNH = 53), not by opioid-specific events or mortality.

sec.p: Prolonged prescription opioid use occurred more often in opioid recipients (4.5% v. 3.3%; adjusted OR 1.54; 95% CI 1.51–1.57; NNH = 59). During the follow-up year, opioid-treated patients received 254 mg more total MMEs (1444 mg v. 1190 mg). Multivariable regression of the natural log-transformed outcome provided an estimate of 1.18, meaning treated patients received 1.18 times as much opioid as controls at 1 year. Figure 2 shows that, among opioid recipients, composite outcomes were most likely in patients with psychotic disorders, substance use disorders, older patients, patients with greater illness burden, and frequent emergency department users. Figure 3 shows that incremental risk, the outcome difference between treated patients and matched controls, was highest for opioid-naive patients, older patients, and males. Patients with documented mental health conditions or substance use had high event rates with or without an opioid prescription; therefore, they experienced minimal incremental risk after opioid prescriptions. Even in the high-risk opioid-naive subgroup, composite outcome differences were driven by all-cause hospital admission and prolonged prescription opioid use, not by opioid-specific events (Appendix 1, Table 2a, available at www.cmaj.ca/lookup/doi/10.1503/cmaj.241542/tab-related-content).

sec.title: Interpretation
sec.p: Patients who received opioids experienced more composite outcomes than matched controls (NNH = 52); however, opioid-specific emergency department visits (e.g., overdoses), new opioid agonist treatment, and mortality were similar between groups. Outcome differences were driven by higher rates of all-cause hospital admission (NNH = 53) and prolonged opioid use (NNH = 59).

These results have practice implications. They provide precise population and subgroup risk estimates. They confirm that single opioid prescriptions are not risk-free but that the likelihood of harm is low and unlikely to outweigh the benefit of treating severe pain. Our findings also show that patient characteristics influence risk and that the outcomes were associated with opioid-naive status, older age, frequent emergency department use, and high illness burden.

The relative effects of opioid prescriptions, intentional misuse, diversion, societal factors, and other opioid exposures on the opioid epidemic are unclear. These knowledge gaps are most pronounced for acute pain management and unscheduled care settings. 14 Composite events occurred in 17.1% of treated patients and 15.7% of controls. This relatively small difference suggests that societal factors and other opioid sources likely play a larger causal role than emergency department prescriptions. To isolate the iatrogenic potential of an emergency department prescription, we estimated incremental risks — differences between treated patients and matched controls. We found that the risk after an opioid prescription did not always correlate with the incremental risk (iatrogenic potential) attributable to that prescription. To illustrate, patients with mental health and substance use disorders had high rates of composite outcomes after opioid prescription but similarly high rates without opioid prescription; therefore, they experienced small incremental risk (NNH = 101 and 649, respectively; Figure 3). Conversely, opioid-naive patients had lower rates of composite outcomes after prescription but high incremental risk (NNH = 21) and had the greatest potential for harm after a prescription. Prescribers should understand the likelihood of adverse outcomes, but also the incremental risk associated with opioid treatment.

Previous emergency department studies were limited to opioid-naive patients and reported estimates from 7 to 300 prescriptions to cause 1 episode of prolonged prescription opioid use.1,2,19,20,37–39 Shah and colleagues found that 6% of opioid recipients continued using opioids beyond a year, but the study was uncontrolled.1 Delgado and colleagues identified a correlation between the amount of opioid prescribed and prolonged use in patients with ankle sprains.40 Hoppe and colleagues reported that an opioid prescription increased the likelihood of subsequent prescriptions (17% v. 10%) but did not adjust for baseline patient differences that might predispose to subsequent prescriptions.20 Friedman and colleagues found that 1% of patients who received opioids in the emergency department exhibited persistent use, and Meisel and colleagues reported that 13.7% developed high-risk use.41,42 Barnett and colleagues found that opioid-naive Medicare patients exposed to high-intensity opioid prescribers had increased rates of prolonged opioid use (NNH = 48)19 but could not replicate this finding in another population.37 Studies of military personnel and adolescents found no association between high-intensity opioid prescribers and subsequent opioid use.38,39

Prolonged opioid use, the outcome used most frequently in previous studies,1,2,19,20,40–42 is important but is not the same as misuse, opioid use disorder, overdose, or adverse health consequences; therefore, we also studied opioid-specific and all-cause outcome events. Our finding that opioid prescriptions were not associated with overdoses, new opioid use disorder treatment, or mortality suggests that these more severe outcomes are unlikely to be caused by prescriptions in the emergency department. However, our finding that prescriptions were associated with subsequent all-cause hospital admission suggests that opioids may cause health events that are not recognized as opioid related.

Future research should evaluate longer-term outcomes and explore the relation between prolonged opioid use and health outcomes. Researchers should investigate agent-specific effects, as all opioids may not be the same, and identify pain syndromes for which opioid risk may be greater or less than treatment benefit. Robust randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are unlikely to be conducted because of ethical concerns (randomly assigning patients with severe pain to non-opioid analgesia), selection bias (patients of greatest interest selecting out), loss to follow-up, and the large samples required to detect small outcome differences. The single RCT evaluating emergency opioid prescription illustrated these problems. Jones and colleagues randomly assigned 350 patients with neck or back pain to oxycodone or placebo during a 6-year enrolment at 157 sites.43 Problems included slow accrual, averaging less than 1 patient per site per year, poor compliance with the study regimen, missing outcome data, and a sample size insufficient to address health events or subgroups. Observational and quasiexperimental studies in large populations are more feasible and, if well done, can yield clinically important results.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: We did not capture social or functional outcomes. We assessed outcomes at 1 year, which may be insufficient to identify all opioid-related sequelae. Because we analyzed emergency department visits, some patients were enrolled multiple times. This breaches the assumption of independent observations; however, adjusting for within-patient correlation is highly unlikely to decrease the precision of the effect estimates or change our conclusions. Although we reliably identified opioid-treated patients, matched controls, and main outcomes, some subgroups were susceptible to misclassification. For example, our definition of opioid use disorder would miss opioid users who had no opioid prescriptions or opioid-related health encounters.

Administrative data may lack important matching variables. We could not ascertain pain severity and instead matched on diagnosis, which is a strong predictor of opioid administration.44 We also matched on sex, visit year, triage acuity, ambulance arrival, and length of stay. To address illness burden, we matched on age, comorbidity, deprivation status, medication use, and prior emergency department use. This rich variable set provided a multidimensional picture of patients and allowed us to generate highly comparable treated and control cohorts. We believe the range of matching variables provided partial coverage for unmeasured covariates; however, confounding by intention (which arises from systematic differences in treatment allocation based on clinicians’ intentions or decisions, influenced by patient characteristics or context) remains a possible source of bias. If our opioid-treated group had more severe pain or other features that prompted physicians to prescribe opioids, this group would be expected to have a worse prognosis and receive more subsequent opioid prescriptions. Confounding by intention would therefore bias our study against opioid treatment, and the actual risk associated with opioid prescription might be less than reported. Our finding of harm with opioid prescription is plausible, and the low level of harm estimated suggests that confounding by intention did not substantially influence our results.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Emergency opioid prescriptions were associated with small increases in subsequent opioid prescription use and hospital admission, particularly in older and opioid-naive patients. They were not associated with opioid-related emergency department visits (e.g., overdoses), new opioid agonist therapy, or mortality. Physicians should understand the concept of patient-specific incremental risks when prescribing opioids for acute pain and prescribe cautiously within high-risk groups.
